div1.head: Talk Given Before the Audience Attending the Dedication Exercises of the Monuments to the Personalities Who Participated in the Yellow Fever Experiments at Camp Lazear, by Leonardo M. Tocantins, December 3, 1952
div1.p:
TALK GIVEN ON DECEMBER 3, 1952, BEFORE THE AUDIENCE ATTENDING THE DEDICATION
EXERCISES OF THE MONUMENTS TO THE PERSONALITIES WHO PARTICIPATED IN THE
YELLOW FEVER EXPERIMENTS AT CAMP LAZEAR.

L. M. Tocantins, M.D., Professor of Clinical and Experimental Medicine
Jefferson Medical College, Philadelphia.
Honorable Minister of Public Health, ladies and gentlemen:

The first time that I had occasion to become acquainted with Carlos Finlay was
through an autographed picture of Finlay which hung in the old Library of Jefferson
Medical College. On investigation I discovered that this Cuban Scientist had gradu-
ated in 1855 from Jefferson Medical College, and that he had spent one year as pupil
of S. Weir Mitchell, a great Philadelphia Physician and Neurologist, who was then one
of the Junior Teachers at Jefferson. Finlay maintained throughout his life close
touch with Philadelphia, his Alma Mater and Dr. Mitchell. TheThis was the same Dr. Mitchell
who, in about 1900, came to the defense of Finlay when he was being vigorously attacked be-
cause of his theories regarding yellow fever transmission.

I have been delegated by my School, Jefferson Medical College, to express
here today, the feelings of pride that we at Jefferson have, for having contributed in a
small way to the scientific formation of this great Cuban Physician, Carlos Finlay,
whose ideas and researches had so much to do with the effective sanitation of Central
and South America.
